title: Case Study: Progressive Muscle Weakness in a Patient with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis
clinical_history: A 55-year-old male patient, a former software engineer, presented with a 6-month history of progressive muscle weakness and wasting in his right arm. He initially noticed difficulty lifting his arm and performing daily activities such as dressing and brushing his teeth. Over time, his symptoms have worsened, and he now experiences weakness in his left arm and both legs. He reports difficulty walking and requires assistance with transfers. He also experiences dysphagia and occasional dysarthria.

nprs.affected_area: Right arm muscle weakness and wasting
Left arm and bilateral leg weakness

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged physical activity, especially with his arms, and fatigue
picture: A 24-hour picture showing progressive muscle weakness and wasting, especially in the upper limbs
medical_history: Recently diagnosed with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) 6 months ago
medications: Riluzole 50mg twice daily, pain management with acetaminophen as needed
personal_history: Married with two children, lives alone with his wife as his children are in college. He is experiencing depression and anxiety due to his condition.
imaging: EMG and nerve conduction studies confirming the diagnosis of ALS
